intro: Andersonglossum virginianum, commonly known as the Virginia tickseed, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the sunflower family (Asteraceae) and is characterized by its bright yellow to orange flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in open woods, meadows, and along roadsides, preferring well-drained soils. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and its flowers are arranged in a flat-topped cluster. The species is known for its ecological importance, providing nectar for pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
